natural problem: Coin $A$ is flipped three times and coin $B$ is flipped four times. What is the probability that the number of heads obtained from flipping the two fair coins is the same?
natural solution: The result will occur when both $A$ and $B$ have either $0,$ $1,$ $2,$ or $3$ heads, and these probabilities are shown in the table. \[ \begin{array}{ccccc} \text{Heads} & 0 & 1 & 2 & 3 \\ \hline {} & & & & \\[-9pt]

A & \dfrac{1}{8} & \dfrac{3}{8} & \dfrac{3}{8} & \dfrac{1}{8} \\[8pt] \hline {} & & & & \\[-9pt] B & \dfrac{1}{16}& \dfrac{4}{16}& \dfrac{6}{16}& \dfrac{4}{16} \end{array} \] The probability of both coins having the same number of heads is \[

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p_A p_B :: "rat"
assumes h0 : "p_A = 1 / 2"
and h1 : "p_B = 1 / 2"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. n \<in> {0, 1, 2, 3, 4} \<longrightarrow> 
  (binomial 3 n * (p_A ^ n) * ((1 - p_A) ^ (3 - n))) *
  (binomial 4 n * (p_B ^ n) * ((1 - p_B) ^ (4 - n))) =
  (35 / 128)"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>n. (binomial 3 n * (p_A ^ n) * ((1 - p_A) ^ (3 - n))) *
  (binomial 4 n * (p_B ^ n) * ((1 - p_B) ^ (4 - n)))) {0, 1, 2, 3, 4} = 35 / 128"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Coin $A$ is flipped three times and coin $B$ is flipped four times. What is the probability that the number of heads obtained from flipping the two fair coins is the same? The final Answer is \frac{35}{128}
 ### Proof
 The result will occur when both $A$ and $B$ have either $0,$ $1,$ $2,$ or $3$ heads, and these probabilities are shown in the table. \[ \begin{array}{ccccc} \text{Heads} & 0 & 1 & 2 & 3 \\ \hline {} & & & & \\[-9pt]
 A & \dfrac{1}{8} & \dfrac{3}{8} & \dfrac{3}{8} & \dfrac{1}{8} \\[8pt] \hline {} & & & & \\[-9pt] B & \dfrac{1}{16}& \dfrac{4}{16}& \dfrac{6}{16}& \dfrac{4}{16} \end{array} \] The probability of both coins having the same number of heads is \[
 \frac{1}{8}\cdot \frac{1}{16} + \frac{3}{8}\cdot \frac{4}{16} + \frac{3}{8}\cdot \frac{6}{16} + \frac{1}{8}\cdot \frac{4}{16} = \boxed{\frac{35}{128}}. \]
 *)

theorem
fixes p_A p_B :: "rat"
assumes h0 : "p_A = 1 / 2"
and h1 : "p_B = 1 / 2"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. n \<in> {0, 1, 2, 3, 4} \<longrightarrow> 
  (binomial 3 n * (p_A ^ n) * ((1 - p_A) ^ (3 - n))) *
  (binomial 4 n * (p_B ^ n) * ((1 - p_B) ^ (4 - n))) =
  (35 / 128)"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>n. (binomial 3 n * (p_A ^ n) * ((1 - p_A) ^ (3 - n))) *
  (binomial 4 n * (p_B ^ n) * ((1 - p_B) ^ (4 - n)))) {0, 1, 2, 3, 4} = 35 / 128"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: In a game, the probability of player A winning any round is $\frac{1}{2}$, and the probability of player B winning any round is also $\frac{1}{2}$. If the probability of player A winning $n$ out of 3 rounds and player B winning $n$ out of 4 rounds is $\frac{35}{128}$ for $n = 0, 1, 2, 3, 4$, find the sum of these probabilities for all values of $n$ in the given range. The final answer is $\frac{35}{128}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p_A p_B :: real
assumes h0 : "p_A = binomial_probability 3 1/2"
and h1 : "p_B = binomial_probability 4 1/2"
shows  "35 / 128 = (\<Sum>k\<in>{0..min 3 4}. p_A k * p_B k)"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Coin $A$ is flipped three times and coin $B$ is flipped four times. What is the probability that the number of heads obtained from flipping the two fair coins is the same? The final Answer is \frac{35}{128}
 ### Proof
 The result will occur when both $A$ and $B$ have either $0,$ $1,$ $2,$ or $3$ heads, and these probabilities are shown in the table. \[ \begin{array}{ccccc} \text{Heads} & 0 & 1 & 2 & 3 \\ \hline {} & & & & \\[-9pt]
 A & \dfrac{1}{8} & \dfrac{3}{8} & \dfrac{3}{8} & \dfrac{1}{8} \\[8pt] \hline {} & & & & \\[-9pt] B & \dfrac{1}{16}& \dfrac{4}{16}& \dfrac{6}{16}& \dfrac{4}{16} \end{array} \] The probability of both coins having the same number of heads is \[
 \frac{1}{8}\cdot \frac{1}{16} + \frac{3}{8}\cdot \frac{4}{16} + \frac{3}{8}\cdot \frac{6}{16} + \frac{1}{8}\cdot \frac{4}{16} = \boxed{\frac{35}{128}}. \]
 *)

theorem
fixes p_A p_B :: real
assumes h0 : "p_A = binomial_probability 3 1/2"
and h1 : "p_B = binomial_probability 4 1/2"
shows  "35 / 128 = (\<Sum>k\<in>{0..min 3 4}. p_A k * p_B k)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the sum of the product of probabilities of obtaining a certain number of successes in two independent binomial experiments, where the first experiment has 3 trials with a success probability of 1/2 and the second experiment has 4 trials with a success probability of 1/2. The sum should be calculated for k ranging from 0 to the minimum of 3 and 4. The final answer is $\frac{35}{128}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p_A p_B :: "rat"
assumes h0 : "p_A = 3"
and h1 : "p_B = 4"
and h2 : "p_A + p_B = 7"
and h3 : "p_A * p_B = 12"
and h4 : "p_A / h2 = 3 / 7"
and h5 : "p_B / h2 = 4 / 7"
shows  "35 / 128 = (h4 powr p_A) * (h5 powr p_B)"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Coin $A$ is flipped three times and coin $B$ is flipped four times. What is the probability that the number of heads obtained from flipping the two fair coins is the same? The final Answer is \frac{35}{128}
 ### Proof
 The result will occur when both $A$ and $B$ have either $0,$ $1,$ $2,$ or $3$ heads, and these probabilities are shown in the table. \[ \begin{array}{ccccc} \text{Heads} & 0 & 1 & 2 & 3 \\ \hline {} & & & & \\[-9pt]
 A & \dfrac{1}{8} & \dfrac{3}{8} & \dfrac{3}{8} & \dfrac{1}{8} \\[8pt] \hline {} & & & & \\[-9pt] B & \dfrac{1}{16}& \dfrac{4}{16}& \dfrac{6}{16}& \dfrac{4}{16} \end{array} \] The probability of both coins having the same number of heads is \[
 \frac{1}{8}\cdot \frac{1}{16} + \frac{3}{8}\cdot \frac{4}{16} + \frac{3}{8}\cdot \frac{6}{16} + \frac{1}{8}\cdot \frac{4}{16} = \boxed{\frac{35}{128}}. \]
 *)

theorem
fixes p_A p_B :: "rat"
assumes h0 : "p_A = 3"
and h1 : "p_B = 4"
and h2 : "p_A + p_B = 7"
and h3 : "p_A * p_B = 12"
and h4 : "p_A / h2 = 3 / 7"
and h5 : "p_B / h2 = 4 / 7"
shows  "35 / 128 = (h4 powr p_A) * (h5 powr p_B)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Suppose $p_A = 3$ and $p_B = 4$, and their sum is 7, i.e., $p_A + p_B = 7$. Their product is 12, i.e., $p_A \cdot p_B = 12$. The fractions $\frac{p_A}{p_A + p_B} = \frac{3}{7}$ and $\frac{p_B}{p_A + p_B} = \frac{4}{7}$. Find the value of $\left(\frac{3}{7}\right)^{3} \cdot \left(\frac{4}{7}\right)^{4}$. The final answer is $\frac{35}{128}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes coin_A coin_B :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "prob coin_A = 1 / 2"
and h1 : "prob coin_B = 1 / 2"
and h2 : "coin_A 3 = (3 choose k)"
and h3 : "coin_B 4 = (4 choose k)"
and h4 : "\<forall> k. 0 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 3 \<longrightarrow> coin_A 3 * coin_B 4 = 35 / 128"
shows  "prob_same_heads coin_A coin_B = 35 / 128"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Coin $A$ is flipped three times and coin $B$ is flipped four times. What is the probability that the number of heads obtained from flipping the two fair coins is the same? The final Answer is \frac{35}{128}
 ### Proof
 The result will occur when both $A$ and $B$ have either $0,$ $1,$ $2,$ or $3$ heads, and these probabilities are shown in the table. \[ \begin{array}{ccccc} \text{Heads} & 0 & 1 & 2 & 3 \\ \hline {} & & & & \\[-9pt]
 A & \dfrac{1}{8} & \dfrac{3}{8} & \dfrac{3}{8} & \dfrac{1}{8} \\[8pt] \hline {} & & & & \\[-9pt] B & \dfrac{1}{16}& \dfrac{4}{16}& \dfrac{6}{16}& \dfrac{4}{16} \end{array} \] The probability of both coins having the same number of heads is \[
 \frac{1}{8}\cdot \frac{1}{16} + \frac{3}{8}\cdot \frac{4}{16} + \frac{3}{8}\cdot \frac{6}{16} + \frac{1}{8}\cdot \frac{4}{16} = \boxed{\frac{35}{128}}. \]
 *)

theorem
fixes coin_A coin_B :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "prob coin_A = 1 / 2"
and h1 : "prob coin_B = 1 / 2"
and h2 : "coin_A 3 = (3 choose k)"
and h3 : "coin_B 4 = (4 choose k)"
and h4 : "\<forall> k. 0 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 3 \<longrightarrow> coin_A 3 * coin_B 4 = 35 / 128"
shows  "prob_same_heads coin_A coin_B = 35 / 128"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: You have two coins, coin A and coin B. The probability of getting heads for coin A is $\frac{1}{2}$ and for coin B is also $\frac{1}{2}$. In three flips of coin A, the probability of getting $k$ heads is given by ${3 \choose k}$, and in four flips of coin B, the probability of getting $k$ heads is given by ${4 \choose k}$. If the probability of getting the same number of heads in three flips of coin A and four flips of coin B is $\frac{35}{128}$, find the probability that the number of heads obtained in both coin flips is the same. The final answer is $\frac{35}{128}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p_A p_B :: "rat"
assumes h0 : "p_A = 1 / 2"
and h1 : "p_B = 1 / 2"
shows  "prob_heads_same = 35 / 128"
where "prob_heads_same = (\<Sum>k\<in>{0..3}. (binomial 3 k) * (binomial 4 k) * (p_A ^ k) * ((1 - p_A) ^ (3 - k)) * (p_B ^ k) * ((1 - p_B) ^ (4 - k)))"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Coin $A$ is flipped three times and coin $B$ is flipped four times. What is the probability that the number of heads obtained from flipping the two fair coins is the same? The final Answer is \frac{35}{128}
 ### Proof
 The result will occur when both $A$ and $B$ have either $0,$ $1,$ $2,$ or $3$ heads, and these probabilities are shown in the table. \[ \begin{array}{ccccc} \text{Heads} & 0 & 1 & 2 & 3 \\ \hline {} & & & & \\[-9pt]
 A & \dfrac{1}{8} & \dfrac{3}{8} & \dfrac{3}{8} & \dfrac{1}{8} \\[8pt] \hline {} & & & & \\[-9pt] B & \dfrac{1}{16}& \dfrac{4}{16}& \dfrac{6}{16}& \dfrac{4}{16} \end{array} \] The probability of both coins having the same number of heads is \[
 \frac{1}{8}\cdot \frac{1}{16} + \frac{3}{8}\cdot \frac{4}{16} + \frac{3}{8}\cdot \frac{6}{16} + \frac{1}{8}\cdot \frac{4}{16} = \boxed{\frac{35}{128}}. \]
 *)

theorem
fixes p_A p_B :: "rat"
assumes h0 : "p_A = 1 / 2"
and h1 : "p_B = 1 / 2"
shows  "prob_heads_same = 35 / 128"
where "prob_heads_same = (\<Sum>k\<in>{0..3}. (binomial 3 k) * (binomial 4 k) * (p_A ^ k) * ((1 - p_A) ^ (3 - k)) * (p_B ^ k) * ((1 - p_B) ^ (4 - k)))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Two coins, A and B, have probabilities of showing heads as $\frac{1}{2}$ and $\frac{1}{2}$, respectively. Find the probability that both coins show the same number of heads after three flips for coin A and four flips for coin B. The final answer is $\frac{35}{128}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p_A p_B :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>k. k \<le> 3 \<longrightarrow> p_A k = (real (binomial 3 k)) / 8"
and h1 : "\<forall>k. k \<le> 4 \<longrightarrow> p_B k = (real (binomial 4 k)) / 16"
shows  "(\<Sum>k\<le>3. p_A k * p_B k) = 35 / 128" (* Probability of the same number of heads from both coins *)
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Coin $A$ is flipped three times and coin $B$ is flipped four times. What is the probability that the number of heads obtained from flipping the two fair coins is the same? The final Answer is \frac{35}{128}
 ### Proof
 The result will occur when both $A$ and $B$ have either $0,$ $1,$ $2,$ or $3$ heads, and these probabilities are shown in the table. \[ \begin{array}{ccccc} \text{Heads} & 0 & 1 & 2 & 3 \\ \hline {} & & & & \\[-9pt]
 A & \dfrac{1}{8} & \dfrac{3}{8} & \dfrac{3}{8} & \dfrac{1}{8} \\[8pt] \hline {} & & & & \\[-9pt] B & \dfrac{1}{16}& \dfrac{4}{16}& \dfrac{6}{16}& \dfrac{4}{16} \end{array} \] The probability of both coins having the same number of heads is \[
 \frac{1}{8}\cdot \frac{1}{16} + \frac{3}{8}\cdot \frac{4}{16} + \frac{3}{8}\cdot \frac{6}{16} + \frac{1}{8}\cdot \frac{4}{16} = \boxed{\frac{35}{128}}. \]
 *)

theorem
fixes p_A p_B :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>k. k \<le> 3 \<longrightarrow> p_A k = (real (binomial 3 k)) / 8"
and h1 : "\<forall>k. k \<le> 4 \<longrightarrow> p_B k = (real (binomial 4 k)) / 16"
shows  "(\<Sum>k\<le>3. p_A k * p_B k) = 35 / 128" (* Probability of the same number of heads from both coins *)
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Two coins are tossed. Coin A is tossed 3 times, and Coin B is tossed 4 times. The probability of getting the same number of heads from both coin tosses is $\frac{35}{128}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob_A prob_B :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<le> 3 \<longrightarrow> prob_A n = (binomial 3 n) / 2 powr 3"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<le> 4 \<longrightarrow> prob_B n = (binomial 4 n) / 2 powr 4"
shows  "prob_A 0 * prob_B 0 + prob_A 1 * prob_B 1 + prob_A 2 * prob_B 2 + prob_A 3 * prob_B 3 = 35 / 128"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Coin $A$ is flipped three times and coin $B$ is flipped four times. What is the probability that the number of heads obtained from flipping the two fair coins is the same? The final Answer is \frac{35}{128}
 ### Proof
 The result will occur when both $A$ and $B$ have either $0,$ $1,$ $2,$ or $3$ heads, and these probabilities are shown in the table. \[ \begin{array}{ccccc} \text{Heads} & 0 & 1 & 2 & 3 \\ \hline {} & & & & \\[-9pt]
 A & \dfrac{1}{8} & \dfrac{3}{8} & \dfrac{3}{8} & \dfrac{1}{8} \\[8pt] \hline {} & & & & \\[-9pt] B & \dfrac{1}{16}& \dfrac{4}{16}& \dfrac{6}{16}& \dfrac{4}{16} \end{array} \] The probability of both coins having the same number of heads is \[
 \frac{1}{8}\cdot \frac{1}{16} + \frac{3}{8}\cdot \frac{4}{16} + \frac{3}{8}\cdot \frac{6}{16} + \frac{1}{8}\cdot \frac{4}{16} = \boxed{\frac{35}{128}}. \]
 *)

theorem
fixes prob_A prob_B :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<le> 3 \<longrightarrow> prob_A n = (binomial 3 n) / 2 powr 3"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<le> 4 \<longrightarrow> prob_B n = (binomial 4 n) / 2 powr 4"
shows  "prob_A 0 * prob_B 0 + prob_A 1 * prob_B 1 + prob_A 2 * prob_B 2 + prob_A 3 * prob_B 3 = 35 / 128"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Consider two events A and B. The probability of event A occurring n times is given by $P_A(n) = \frac{\binom{3}{n}}{2^3}$, where $0 \leq n \leq 3$. The probability of event B occurring n times is given by $P_B(n) = \frac{\binom{4}{n}}{2^4}$, where $0 \leq n \leq 4$. Find the value of $P_A(0)P_B(0) + P_A(1)P_B(1) + P_A(2)P_B(2) + P_A(3)P_B(3)$. The final answer is $\frac{35}{128}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob_same :: real
assumes h0 : "prob_same = (\<Sum>x \<in> {0, 1, 2, 3}. (binomial 3 x * binomial 4 x)) / (2 powr 7)"
shows  "prob_same = 35 / 128"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Coin $A$ is flipped three times and coin $B$ is flipped four times. What is the probability that the number of heads obtained from flipping the two fair coins is the same? The final Answer is \frac{35}{128}
 ### Proof
 The result will occur when both $A$ and $B$ have either $0,$ $1,$ $2,$ or $3$ heads, and these probabilities are shown in the table. \[ \begin{array}{ccccc} \text{Heads} & 0 & 1 & 2 & 3 \\ \hline {} & & & & \\[-9pt]
 A & \dfrac{1}{8} & \dfrac{3}{8} & \dfrac{3}{8} & \dfrac{1}{8} \\[8pt] \hline {} & & & & \\[-9pt] B & \dfrac{1}{16}& \dfrac{4}{16}& \dfrac{6}{16}& \dfrac{4}{16} \end{array} \] The probability of both coins having the same number of heads is \[
 \frac{1}{8}\cdot \frac{1}{16} + \frac{3}{8}\cdot \frac{4}{16} + \frac{3}{8}\cdot \frac{6}{16} + \frac{1}{8}\cdot \frac{4}{16} = \boxed{\frac{35}{128}}. \]
 *)

theorem
fixes prob_same :: real
assumes h0 : "prob_same = (\<Sum>x \<in> {0, 1, 2, 3}. (binomial 3 x * binomial 4 x)) / (2 powr 7)"
shows  "prob_same = 35 / 128"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Find the probability that the sum of the same number of heads and tails appears when flipping 3 coins and 4 coins, respectively. The final answer is $\frac{35}{128}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: real
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum>i\<in>{0..3}. (3 choose i) * (4 choose i)) / (2 powr 3 * 2 powr 4)"
shows  "P = 35 / 128"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Coin $A$ is flipped three times and coin $B$ is flipped four times. What is the probability that the number of heads obtained from flipping the two fair coins is the same? The final Answer is \frac{35}{128}
 ### Proof
 The result will occur when both $A$ and $B$ have either $0,$ $1,$ $2,$ or $3$ heads, and these probabilities are shown in the table. \[ \begin{array}{ccccc} \text{Heads} & 0 & 1 & 2 & 3 \\ \hline {} & & & & \\[-9pt]
 A & \dfrac{1}{8} & \dfrac{3}{8} & \dfrac{3}{8} & \dfrac{1}{8} \\[8pt] \hline {} & & & & \\[-9pt] B & \dfrac{1}{16}& \dfrac{4}{16}& \dfrac{6}{16}& \dfrac{4}{16} \end{array} \] The probability of both coins having the same number of heads is \[
 \frac{1}{8}\cdot \frac{1}{16} + \frac{3}{8}\cdot \frac{4}{16} + \frac{3}{8}\cdot \frac{6}{16} + \frac{1}{8}\cdot \frac{4}{16} = \boxed{\frac{35}{128}}. \]
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: real
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum>i\<in>{0..3}. (3 choose i) * (4 choose i)) / (2 powr 3 * 2 powr 4)"
shows  "P = 35 / 128"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Find the probability P, where P is defined as the sum of the products of the binomial coefficients ${3 \choose i}$ and ${4 \choose i}$ divided by $2^3 \cdot 2^4$, for $i$ ranging from 0 to 3. The final answer is $\frac{35}{128}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum>k\<in>{0..3}. (fact 3 / (fact k * fact (3 - k))) * (fact 4 / (fact k * fact (4 - k)))) / (2 powr 7)"
shows  "P = 35 / 128"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Coin $A$ is flipped three times and coin $B$ is flipped four times. What is the probability that the number of heads obtained from flipping the two fair coins is the same? The final Answer is \frac{35}{128}
 ### Proof
 The result will occur when both $A$ and $B$ have either $0,$ $1,$ $2,$ or $3$ heads, and these probabilities are shown in the table. \[ \begin{array}{ccccc} \text{Heads} & 0 & 1 & 2 & 3 \\ \hline {} & & & & \\[-9pt]
 A & \dfrac{1}{8} & \dfrac{3}{8} & \dfrac{3}{8} & \dfrac{1}{8} \\[8pt] \hline {} & & & & \\[-9pt] B & \dfrac{1}{16}& \dfrac{4}{16}& \dfrac{6}{16}& \dfrac{4}{16} \end{array} \] The probability of both coins having the same number of heads is \[
 \frac{1}{8}\cdot \frac{1}{16} + \frac{3}{8}\cdot \frac{4}{16} + \frac{3}{8}\cdot \frac{6}{16} + \frac{1}{8}\cdot \frac{4}{16} = \boxed{\frac{35}{128}}. \]
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum>k\<in>{0..3}. (fact 3 / (fact k * fact (3 - k))) * (fact 4 / (fact k * fact (4 - k)))) / (2 powr 7)"
shows  "P = 35 / 128"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find the value of the probability P, defined as the sum of the products of the binomial coefficients for k in the range 0 to 3, where the binomial coefficients are computed using the formula $\frac{\text{fact}(3)}{\text{fact}(k) * \text{fact}(3 - k)}$ and $\frac{\text{fact}(4)}{\text{fact}(k) * \text{fact}(4 - k)}$, divided by $2^{7}$. The final answer is $\frac{35}{128}$.
